<title level="1" pfs="Standard">[Dig-Widget](/Monsters.aspx?ID=771)</title>

<row gap="medium">

<column gap="medium" flex="1 1 400px">

Thieves covet dig-widgets, specialized constructs built for infiltration. Each dig-widget contains numerous simple tools, including a set of mechanical devices that function as [thieves' tools](/Equipment.aspx?ID=58), two arms with drills, and two arms with corkscrews for attaching to and climbing surfaces. Once activated, these devices propel themselves forward. Though they have the full faculties typical of a construct, they usually follow a simple routine: avoid notice, pick any lock barring the path, dig past obstacles, and attack if caught. They're rarely left unattended, as a thief needs to be nearby to follow after-both to steal goods and to stop the dig-widget from engaging in further larceny once it's achieved its goal.

 The source of a dig-widget's power is as much mechanical as it is magical. The gears and springs that provide a dig-widget mobility are an improvement over more primitive true clockwork creations (whose functions require constant winding to remain mobile), but at the cost of security, for a dig-widget's moving parts can be dismantled quickly by thieves and others with the proper training.

<column gap="tiny">
**[Recall Knowledge - Construct](/Rules.aspx?ID=563)**
([Arcana](/Skills.aspx?ID=2), [Crafting](/Skills.aspx?ID=4)): DC 20

**[Unspecific Lore](/Rules.aspx?ID=563)**: DC 18

**[Specific Lore](/Rules.aspx?ID=563)**: DC 15
</column>

</column>

<column gap="medium">
<image src="/images/Monsters/DigWidget.png" />
</column>

</row>

<title level="2" right="Creature 5">[Dig-Widget](/Monsters.aspx?ID=771)</title>

<traits>
<trait label="N" url="/Rules.aspx?ID=95" />
<trait label="Small" />
<trait label="Construct" url="/Traits.aspx?ID=35" />
<trait label="Mindless" url="/Traits.aspx?ID=108" />
</traits>

<column gap="tiny">

<row gap="tiny">**Source** [Bestiary 2](/Sources.aspx?ID=32) pg. 79 <sup>2.0</sup></row>

**Perception** +9; [darkvision](/MonsterAbilities.aspx?ID=12), [tremorsense (imprecise) 30 feet](/MonsterAbilities.aspx?ID=40)

**Languages**

**Skills**
[Acrobatics](/Skills.aspx?ID=1) +12, [Athletics](/Skills.aspx?ID=3) +9, [Stealth](/Skills.aspx?ID=15) +14, [Thievery](/Skills.aspx?ID=17) +15

<row gap="medium">
**Str** +2

**Dex** +5

**Con** +1

**Int** -5

**Wis** +0

**Cha** -5
</row>

**Infiltration Tools** A dig-widget's face consists of a set of [infiltrator thieves' tools](/Equipment.aspx?ID=58). They can be salvaged from a destroyed dig-widget with a successful DC 20 [Crafting](/Skills.aspx?ID=4) check. On a failed check, the tools are destroyed.

</column>

---

<column gap="tiny">

<row gap="medium">
**AC** 23 

**Fort** +10 

**Ref** +14 

**Will** +7 

</row>

**HP** 65

**Immunities**
bleed, [death](/Traits.aspx?ID=40) effects, [disease](/Traits.aspx?ID=46), [doomed](/Conditions.aspx?ID=9), [drained](/Conditions.aspx?ID=10), [fatigued](/Conditions.aspx?ID=15), [healing](/Traits.aspx?ID=89), [mental](/Traits.aspx?ID=106), [necromancy](/Traits.aspx?ID=117), nonlethal attacks, [paralyzed](/Conditions.aspx?ID=28), [poison](/Traits.aspx?ID=126), [sickened](/Conditions.aspx?ID=34), [unconscious](/Conditions.aspx?ID=38)

**Mechanical Vulnerability** A creature with expert proficiency in [Thievery](/Skills.aspx?ID=17) can attempt a check to [Disable a Device](/Actions.aspx?ID=69) to damage a dig-widget. The DC is 22, and each success deals 20 damage.

</column>

---

<column gap="tiny">

**Speed** 30 feet, burrow 15 feet

**Melee**
<actions string="Single Action" />
drill +14 ([fatal d10](/Traits.aspx?ID=178), [Finesse](/Traits.aspx?ID=179)),
**Damage** 2d6+4 piercing plus 1d6 [persistent bleed](/Conditions.aspx?ID=29)

**Melee**
<actions string="Single Action" />
corkscrew +14 ([Finesse](/Traits.aspx?ID=179)),
**Damage** 2d8+4 piercing

**Fastening Leap** <actions string="Single Action" />  The dig-widget Leaps up 20 feet onto a creature or object and attempts a corkscrew Strike against it. If the Strike damages the target, the dig-widget attaches to the target (typically to the back of a creature). This is similar to [Grabbing](/MonsterAbilities.aspx?ID=18) the creature, but the dig-widget moves with that creature rather than holding it in place. While attached, the dig-widget can't use its corkscrew. The dig-widget can be [Shoved](/Actions.aspx?ID=38) off, or it can detach itself with an Interact action.

**[Sneak Attack](/MonsterAbilities.aspx?ID=34)**   A dig-widget's Strikes deal an additional 1d6 precision damage to [flat-footed](/Conditions.aspx?ID=16) creatures.

</column>

<aside>
<title level="2" noclass="true" icon="/images/Icons/Sidebar_2_AdditionalLore.png">Widget Workshops</title>

The first dig-widget came from the workshops of a [dwarven](/Ancestries.aspx?ID=1) thieves' guild called Godak's Grifters, which used more advanced magical clockwork theories as a springboard for these simpler but no less effective contraptions. With their dig-widgets, the Grifters plagued the authorities of several dwarven settlements over the years. Their travels spread dig-widget technology, and numerous improvements have since led to faster and more reliable versions. Though upstanding dwarven mechanics have observed dig-widgets and recognized the complexity of the technology, they've steadfastly refused to adapt something with such an unscrupulous origin.
</aside>
